channel.title: BBC News - World
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Female journalist who interviewed Taliban flees
item.description: Beheshta Arghand, who made headlines when she interviewed the Taliban, has spoken out after fleeing the country.

item.title: Texas passes law banning abortion after six weeks
item.description: The law, one of the most restrictive in the US, passes as the Supreme Court fails to block it.

item.title: Japan finds black particles in Moderna vaccine
item.description: It comes less than a week after the country suspended more than a million doses due to contamination.

item.title: Hurricane Ida: Before and after images reveal devastation
item.description: Aerial photographs reveal damage and flooding in parts of Louisiana following Hurricane Ida.

item.title: Climate change: Big increase in weather disasters over the past five decades
item.description: Floods, storms and extreme events increase five-fold but the number of people dying in them fell.

item.title: Zambian President Hichilema inherits 'empty treasury'
item.description: Corruption is at "horrifying" levels, Hakainde Hichilema tells the BBC, a week after being sworn in.

item.title: International Space Station facing irreparable failures, Russia warns
item.description: The majority of in-flight systems on the ISS have passed their expiry date, an official warns.

item.title: Air pollution may reduce life expectancy of Indians by nine years, says study
item.description: Millions in north India face the most extreme levels of air pollution in the world, the report says.

item.title: South America's drought-hit Paraná river at 77-year low
item.description: The Paraná is a key waterway for shipping and also provides drinking water for millions of people.

item.title: Italian police guard train stations as Covid pass rolled-out
item.description: Anti-vaccination protesters say they will target rail services in more than 50 cities.

item.title: Tonga royals deny Australia horse trainer murder link
item.description: It has addressed tabloid allegations that the late king was involved in covering up a 1980s killing.

item.title: One in three trees face extinction in wild, says new report
item.description: Experts say 17,500 tree species are at risk around the world, including magnolias, oaks and maples.

item.title: Gulf Sky: 'Our ship was hijacked and taken to Iran'
item.description: Former crew of the oil tanker Gulf Sky talk publically for the first time about the ship's disappearance.

item.title: Marseille drugs: Child victims of French city's vicious gang war
item.description: A 14-year-old is the latest victim of Marseille's gang war, prompting a key visit from President Macron.

item.title: My last despatch before Russian expulsion
item.description: The BBC's Moscow correspondent files her final despatch after more than 20 years reporting in Russia.

item.title: Does feeding garden birds do more harm than good?
item.description: How bird feeding could disrupt an ecological balance just beyond our windowsills and gardens.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'I was making money, but had no money'
item.description: Honey boss Scott Davies says cash flow problems meant though he was profitable he "had no money".

item.title: Nigerian students amass degrees to stay in Europe
item.description: Modupe Osunkoya enrolled on her third post-graduate degree because she says there are no jobs at home.

item.title: Former Afghan minister: Women fearful but walking the streets
item.description: Former Afghan finance minister Omar Zakhilwal says there is no alternative to working with the Taliban.

item.title: Biden defends pulling US troops out before all Americans evacuated
item.description: Joe Biden defends his decision to pull US troops out of Afghanistan before all Americans were evacuated.

item.title: Afghanistan: 'Struggle to survive or race to escape' on streets of Kabul
item.description: The BBC's Lyse Doucet reports from the Afghan capital, a day after the last US troops left.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban enter Kabul airport and celebrate by posing in aircraft
item.description: The group entered the Afghan capital's airport hours after the last US soldier left the country.

item.title: Caldor Fire: Thousands flee as Lake Tahoe under threat
item.description: Traffic clogs evacuation routes as residents and tourists flee from the encroaching Caldor Fire.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban asked if there will be a place for women in new government
item.description: In a BBC Pashto interview, the leadership was questioned about how the group intend to govern the country.

item.title: Afghanistan: UK and Taliban in talks over further evacuations
item.description: A UK official is in Qatar for talks to secure the exit of both UK and Afghan nationals, No 10 says.

item.title: Amid violent reprisals, Afghans fear the Taliban's 'amnesty' was empty
item.description: Reports suggest the Taliban are searching for, and allegedly killing, people they pledged to leave in peace.

item.title: Afghanistan: How can the West stop terror bases?
item.description: The foreign secretary says the UK will fight ISIS-K by all means available - but what does that mean?

item.title: What was left behind by US forces?
item.description: As US troops took off from Kabul, they abandoned 73 aircraft - all disabled.
